item.title: Les bars vont officiellement rouvrir partout au Québec et voici ce qui sera permis ou non
item.content:encoded:
Le plan de déconfinement du gouvernement bat son plein et les bars vont officiellement rouvrir partout au Québec à partir de ce vendredi 11 juin.

En conférence de presse ce 8 juin, François Legault a annoncé que « tout le Québec va être soit en jaune soit en vert » d'ici le 14 juin. Grâce à ce changement de palier les mesures s'assoupliront, donc voici ce qui sera permis ou non dans les bars.

Très fier d’avoir annoncé que tout le Québec passera en jaune ou en vert, et ce dès lundi prochain! Bravo à tous… https://t.co/ktAxYoXvy2
— François Legault (@François Legault) 1623184988.0


Quand est-ce que les bars vont pouvoir rouvrir officiellement?

Les terrasses des bars pourront officiellement rouvrir à partir de ce 11 juin dans les régions qui changent de palier de la zone orange pour la zone jaune comme à Montréal et Laval, la Capitale-Nationale, la Montérégie, les Laurentides, Lanaudière, l'Estrie, l'Outaouais, en Chaudière-Appalaches et dans tout le Bas-Saint-Laurent.

Les bars étaient déjà ouverts depuis le 26 mars pour les régions qui étaient encore en jaune et qui sont depuis passées au vert. C'est le cas en Abitibi-Témiscamingue, en Gaspésie–Îles-de-la-Madeleine, sur la Côte-Nord et dans le Nord-du-Québec.

Est-ce que tu pourras prendre un verre à l'intérieur?

À partir de ce lundi 14 juin, il sera possible de prendre un verre à l'intérieur des bars, car les régions initialement en zone orange passent au jaune.

Cependant, le gouvernement prévoit toujours une « distance de deux mètres entre les tables » et il te sera interdit de chanter et de danser si tu n'es pas assis.e.

Les bars fermeront tous à minuit et la vente d'alcool cessera à 23 h.

À combien tu peux y aller?

En zone jaune, le site du gouvernement prévoit que « les occupant.es provenant de plus de deux résidences privées » pourront prendre un verre à la même table.

En zone verte, « un maximum de dix personnes par table ou les occupant.es de trois résidences » seront accepté.es, peut-on lire dans un communiqué.

Dans les deux zones, les bars devront maintenir la fréquentation de leurs établissements à 50 % de la capacité maximale prévue et tenir un registre des clients.

item.title: There’s A New Canadian-Made Craft Vodka & It’s Perfect For Summertime Cocktails
item.content:encoded:
The sight of flowers blooming, the sound of a sizzling barbecue, the taste of a fruity cocktail enjoyed under the sun — the signs of summer are finally here, and Canadians will not waste one single sunny day of their favourite season.

While some restrictions remain in place across th e country, the good news is that you can still get the best of summertime, just closer to home. Exploring your own backyard, relaxing on your private patio oasis with a summer cocktail in hand and supporting your city's local businesses are just a few of your options for making the most of this time of the year.

This season, you can support local Canadian businesses with every sip you take, from the vodka you use as your cocktail base to the strawberry slice garnishing your aperitif.

Northern Keep Vodka is a new Canadian craft spirit made from rye and winter wheat — ingredients grown right at our own backyards by Canadian farmers. Distilled five times for a finish so smooth you can sip it on ice, Northern Keep boasts hints of citrus and spice and is crafted by the artisans of the award-winning Alberta Distillers.

But Northern Keep is more than just a delicious, Canadian-made vodka. The team at Northern Keep is also focused on sustainability and protecting the lands the crops used to make the spirit come from! Each bottle of Northern Keep sold helps to protect five square feet of ecologically significant Canadian land in partnership with the Nature Conservancy of Canada.

If you're ready to up your mixology game, you can start with these five recipes ranging from simple to a little more complex. Pair each one with fresh, local and in-season ingredients to create your next go-to summer drink.

"Keep It Cool" & Simple With This Tart Take

​Courtesy of Northern Keep Vodka

Ingredients:

  • 1 oz. (30 ml) Northern Keep Vodka
  • The juice of half of a lime
  • Grapefruit soda to taste

This delicious cocktail, with its slightly tart and refreshing flavour profile, is a welcome addition to the hottest of summer days. To bring this drink to life, pour some Northern Keep Vodka, grapefruit soda and lime juice over ice, and don't forget your lime wedge for garnish. To add some flare to the "Keep It Cool" cocktail, salt the rim of your glass beforehand.

Keep Things Smooth & Sweet With "That's My Jam"

Courtesy of Northern Keep Vodka

Ingredients:

  • 1 oz. (30 ml) Northern Keep Vodka
  • 1 tablespoon raspberry jam
  • 2 oz. (60 ml) pineapple juice

Raspberry jam doesn't have to be limited to a PB&J sandwich! For this sweeter cocktail, shake vodka, jam and juice with ice for 15 seconds, then strain into a chilled coupe glass. Garnish your smooth and fruity beverage with a slice of pineapple and pretend you're in an island paradise.

Chill Out With "Keep Calm," A Refreshing Green Tea Twist

Courtesy of Northern Keep Vodka

Ingredients:

  • 1 oz. (30 ml) Northern Keep Vodka
  • 1 oz. (30 ml) cranberry juice
  • 3 oz. (90 ml) green tea (chilled)

The flavour profile of this drink is light, effortless and refreshing — like the perfect summer evening. Grab some Northern Keep Vodka, cranberry juice and chilled green tea, then shake it all up with some ice for about 15 seconds. Strain your cocktail into a highball glass filled with (more) ice, use some mint to garnish, and voilà!

"Keep It Together" With This Fruit-Infused Cocktail

Courtesy of Northern Keep Vodka

Ingredients:

  • 1 oz. (30 ml) Northern Keep Vodka
  • 1 oz. (30 ml) honey syrup (equal parts honey and water combined together over low heat)
  • 3 diced strawberries
  • 3 lime wedges
  • 8-10 mint leaves
  • Soda water

This one takes a little more work, but the "Keep It Together" cocktail is refreshing on a hot summer day. Muddle together your mint, strawberries, lime, and syrup in a highball glass, and then add some ice, Northern Keep Vodka, and top up with soda. Stir your creation to bring the muddled ingredients afloat and garnish this next-level beverage with a sprig of fresh mint.

Freshen Up With This "Grapefruit Basil Smash"

Courtesy of Northern Keep Vodka

Ingredients:

  • 1.5 oz. (45 ml) Northern Keep Vodka
  • 1 oz. (30 ml) grapefruit juice
  • 2 teaspoons lemon juice
  • 4 teaspoons simple syrup (equal parts sugar and water combined over low heat until sugar dissolves)
  • 0.5 oz. (15 ml) hibiscus tea (unsweetened and chilled)
  • 6 basil leaves (plus an additional sprig for garnish)

This citrus-forward cocktail makes the most of Northern Keep Vodka's refreshing flavour profile. The tartness of the grapefruit and bitterness of lemon are balanced by the sweet simple syrup and floral hibiscus tea, with the herbal aroma of fresh basil bringing it all together.

You'll need a muddler and a shaker for this two-step cocktail. Start by muddling the basil leaves in the shaker before throwing in the vodka, juices, syrup, tea, and ice and give it a good shake. Strain your "Grapefruit Basil Smash" onto fresh ice in a rocks glass and garnish with a slice of grapefruit and some fresh basil before putting your feet up and relaxing in the sun.

Uniquely made using the finest ingredients grown in Canada, Northern Keep is a great addition to your drinks menu this summer. Plus, with Northern Keep's partnership with the Nature Conservancy of Canada, you can take each sip knowing you've done some good, too.

Northern Keep Vodka

Price: $30.95 (price varies slightly depending on location)

Where: Find Northern Keep at your local LCBO

Details: Canada's new premium craft vodka is made with local ingredients by expert distillers to create a smooth-drinking vodka with notes of citrus and spice. Each bottle sold also supports Canada's natural environment through a partnership with the Nature Conservancy of Canada.

To learn more about Northern Keep Vodka, check out Northern Keep's website or follow them on Facebook and Instagram.

item.title: François Legault dévoile des détails sur son bal de finissants « mémorable »
item.content:encoded:
En annonçant que les bals de finissant.es allaient finalement avoir lieu au Québec, François Legault y est allé de petites confessions entourant ses souvenirs de jeunesse. Une chose est sûre, son âge a été trahi.

C'est ce mardi 8 juin, lors d'une conférence de presse quant à la situation entourant la COVID-19 au Québec, que le premier ministre s'est avancé sur son passé d'élève du secondaire.


La situation de la pandémie continue de s’améliorer. Notre plan de déconfinement fonctionne et on peut même le deva… https://t.co/Qe36Gwmo9K
— François Legault (@François Legault) 1623171159.0


« On se rappelle tous... En tout cas, moi, je me rappelle mon bal au secondaire, lance-t-il d'emblée. Ça avait eu lieu aux Vaudreuil Inn qui, malheureusement, n'existent plus aujourd'hui. C'était à Dorion. »

Selon les dires de M. Legault, les festivités entourant son rite de passage, dont des milliers de jeunes Québécois. es n'ont pu vivre lors de la première vague de la pandémie, ont fini « aux petites heures du matin » et « ç'a été mémorable ».

Cette année, les élèves finissant.es du secondaire pourront vivre leur bal en bonne et due forme, mais plus tard qu'à l'habitude, soit à compter du 8 juillet prochain. La décision de retarder la tenue de cette soirée a été prise en se basant sur le fait que la majorité des jeunes devrait avoir reçu une dose d'ici le 24 juin.

Les festivités devront se dérouler à l'extérieur sous des chapiteaux avec un maximum de 250 personnes. Les « rapprochements de toute sorte » seront permis, a affirmé François Legault.

item.title: This 5-Day Adventure Itinerary Is The Most Perfect Way To Experience Whistler This Summer
item.content:encoded:
As Vancouverites and residents across B.C. begin planning their sunny season vacations, many are looking to Whistler as their escape to fun, wellness and nature. With restrictions beginning to ease and laid-back summer days on the horizon, it's the perfect excuse to book a longer stay this year, giving you plenty of time to discover everything the resort has to offer.

Visitors to Whistler will find that there are plenty of activities still available, but like any pandemic-era vacation, planning ahead is key. Make sure to do your research, consult the Doors Open Directory to see what's open and how businesses are responding to COVID-19 measures, and make reservations in advance so businesses can prepare. This is the best way for you to have a good time too.

If Whistler is on your list of dream destinations, consider taking a midweek trip. This way, you can enjoy a quieter Whistler and get to do everything you've had your eye on. Plus, you will score the best rates.

Right now, Whistler is offering four-night stays from $104 per night, and if you want to stay longer, you can opt for a seven-night stay for just $93 per night. You'll also receive an adventure voucher, ranging from $50 to $100, to put toward the Whistler activity of your dreams.

To start planning your trip, check out these must-do activities along with some tips and tricks you need to know before visiting Whistler.

Day 1: Fuel Up On Tasty Eats In Town 

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by 𝓢𝓸𝓹𝓱𝓲𝓪+𝓙𝓸𝓷 | Vancouver Foodies (@sopheats)

Nothing helps you fuel up like a good meal. Whistler has tons of restaurants to experience, and lots of fantastic outdoor patios to enjoy your meal al fresco. Be sure to make a reservation because tables go fast these days.

Whether you're with friends or your partner, you can enjoy some cocktails at the Four Seasons' Vintage Camper or sign up to take part in a Whistler Tasting Tour.

Another way to get amped up is to head off the beaten track. Try visiting areas that are less populated for the best experience. One of Whistler's cooler neighbourhoods, Function Junction, features vintage shops, cafes, breweries, and even axe throwing.

Day 2: Get Your Adrenaline Pumping

Whistler is a haven for daredevils. Take on Whistler's whitewater rafting tour at Wedge Rafting, where you can get your heart pumping and enjoy an exhilarating view of the landscape at the same time.

If you're willing to venture further, look into Canadian Wilderness Adventures E-bike tours that take you on a ride through the old-growth forests alongside Callaghan Creek and out toward the incredible Alexander Falls.

For the ultimate adrenaline-boosting experience, face your fears at Whistler Bungee, where you can take a harnessed plunge over the raging river. Locals vote this bungee bridge "the most extreme activity in Whistler."

Day 3: Adventure Deeper

Take your adventure further with the Peak 2 Peak gondola ride, where you can witness the spectacular alpine landscape with a view like no other. On your journey, you'll experience the stunning scenery between Whistler and Blackcomb mountains. From ancient glaciers to coastal rainforests and sky-high volcanic peaks, this 11-minute lift is no ordinary gondola ride.

If you want to take things higher, you could hop on a local flight with Blackcomb Helicopters. Hover over Whistler and enjoy sights of the Coast Mountains from great heights.

For those who don't mind getting a little dirty, there are RZR tours. Rip through the rugged backcountry trails in an RZR, weaving through the breathtaking forest while getting the thrill you came to find.

Day 4: Try Something New

Courtesy of Whistler Sliding Centre

Pay a visit to the venue for the 2010 Olympic games at Whistler Olympic Park. Channel your inner Olympian with a summer bobsleigh experience. This unique attraction will see you shooting down the track used by bobsleigh, skeleton and luge athletes each winter. Driven by an experienced pilot, the wheeled sleds reach speeds of up to 90 km/h. All the proceeds from your ride go back into growing the sport, so you'll be helping out the athletes too!

If you've never had the pleasure of riding a horse, pay Copper Cayuse a visit and enjoy an exclusive horseback riding tour for a peaceful, socially distanced saunter through the wilderness.

For those who love interactive experiences, Vallea Lumina offers night-time multimedia walks through the woods that promise enchanting secrets hidden among the trees and in the shadows.

Day 5: Wind Down

After four days of adrenaline-filled activities and nonstop exploring, it's time for a little TLC. Enjoy some self-care at Scandinave Spa with a massage before relaxing in the baths.

Spending time in nature is another excellent way to relax. Take an interpretive walk with a guide on the Eco Tour in Wayside Park and connect with the environment. Visitors are encouraged to bring their own bike this summer to ride along the Valley Trail and explore Whistler on their own terms.

Bikes can be parked at the secure Bike Valet at Olympic Plaza, Rainbow Park or Lost Lake Park. Summer construction projects in Whistler may affect vehicle access, so not only will biking help reach environmental goals but ensure a smooth transportation journey.

Whistler's lakes and parks are usually busy in summer. If you're excited to spend time on the water, plan ahead so you can have a relaxing time. With limited parking it may be better to leave the car and hop on public transit (which is free on weekends and public holidays), walk, or ride your bike. Booking a guided tour is a great way to make sure you get time on the water in case the parks are at full capacity.

The Whistler Insider blog is a knowledgeable source packed with need-to-know information to help plan your trip. Just remember: when it comes to COVID-19 restrictions and guidelines, it's crucial you know before you go

To learn more about planning your summer vacation at Whistler, check out the town's website or follow them on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, or YouTube.

item.title: These 9 Signs Prove That Canadian Life Is Starting To Get Back To Normal
item.content:encoded:
It has been a long and difficult year for people around the world as the COVID-19 pandemic dramatically altered life as we knew it.

While the pandemic is still very much present, we are beginning to see some signs of going back to normal in Canada.

As many provinces and territories make significant strides towards reopening and things we used to take for granted (like eating at restaurants or going to the movies) begin to come back into the fold, it's worth celebrating the shifts towards pre-COVID-19 life.

We've rounded up a list of some signs that Canada is starting to get back to normal and we're pretty sure we'll never take those little pleasures for granted again.

Here are some things unfolding around our country that that give us a little sense of nostalgia and excitement.

The Calgary Stampede Is Making A Comeback

The Calgary Stampede, also known as the greatest outdoor show on Earth, has announced that it will be making a comeback in July 2021. While the festival will be a little bit different than what we've seen in the past, you can still expect a ton of food, rides, beer gardens, rodeo activities and so much more. Alberta is slated to move into the final stage of the provincial reopening plan in early July, which is just in time for Stampede, should everything go as planned.

BC Is Bring Back Recreational Travel Within The Province

British Columbians have been under strict travel restrictions for a while now, confining them to their health regions only. But during step two of the reopening plan, locals will be able to move freely around the province once more. So camping, visits to the Island and road trips are back on the itinerary for summer.

Montreal's Terrasses Are Back In Action

If you've ever been to Montreal, you know that locals take patio season very seriously. Patios (known as terrasses in Quebec) have started to open back up and they are already exploding with excited Montrealers enjoying summer weather and drinks. Restaurant patios are and bar patios are slated to open on June 11, each of which has some health measures in place. Nothing says summer like an outdoor drink in Montreal.

NHLers Will Be Crossing The Border

The Stanley Cup Semifinals and Finals are on the way and the Government of Canada has agreed to make an exemption to border restrictions so that American NHLers can come over and play on Canadian soil. Nothing says pre-pandemic life more than a massive sporting event, even more so between two teams from different countries.

Billie Eilish's World Tour Is Coming To Canada

It's no secret that Canadians have been missing live music throughout the pandemic, so why not kick down the door with one of music's biggest names and go see Billie Eilish in person? The superstar will be coming to Montreal, Toronto, and Vancouver in winter and spring of 2022 and tickets are already on sale.

Ontario Is Moving Into Step 1 Of Reopening

After a long year of restrictions and lockdowns, Ontario is moving into step one of the province's reopening plan on Friday, June 11. Things like outdoor gatherings and patio dining will be back on the agenda, and luckily, this is unfolding just in time for another scorching summer in Ontario.

100-Person Outdoor Gatherings Are Allowed In Yukon

Yukon is seriously loosening its COVID-19 restrictions and a big part of that has to do with gatherings. As of now, Yukoners can gather in groups of 20 indoors with masks and groups of up to 100 outdoors with physical distancing. If you haven't seen your friends in a while, imagine seeing 99 of them (at a distance, of course).

Cineplex Is Reopening Across Alberta

If you've been missing the movie-going experience, you don't have to miss it for much longer. Cineplex theatres are reopening across Alberta on June 10 and there are some exciting new releases for your viewing pleasure. Of course, there are health measures in place.

Two-Dose Fall

Justin Trudeau says that we can look forward to a "one-dose summer" where some health restrictions can be lifted. But beyond that, he says we can get hyped for a "two-dose fall," when most Canadians will have two COVID-19 vaccine doses and we can return to a relatively normal, pre-pandemic life. We've been through it over the past several months, and we're starting to see the light at the end of the tunnel.

item.title: An Intense Storm Is About To Make Toronto's Weather Go From 0 To 100 Real Quick
item.content:encoded:
If you had a walk or picnic planned this afternoon, you may want to rain check. Environment Canada has issued special weather statements throughout the GTA including Toronto, Peel, Halton, and York Region and other regions around southern Ontario.

The weather alerts in the GTA call for isolated thunderstorms that will travel across the regions throughout the afternoon, accompanied by wind gusts of up to 70 kilometres per hour and local rainfall amounts of 20 to 40 millimetres falling "in an hour or less."

Drivers should use extra caution as there could suddenly be very low visibility while driving on the roads, says Environment Canada. Poorly drained areas of highways can lead to difficult driving conditions as a result of the intense downpours.

The treacherous weather is expected to end sometime this evening, so until then, it's best to stay vigilant and not stray too far from a safe place to hide from the elements.

This week has brought thunderstorm activity to other parts of Ontario as well, along with the risk of large hail.

item.title: Stop Everything, You Can Win A Future Trip To Italy & Here’s How
item.content:encoded:
If you've spent the better part of the last year dreaming of soaring the skies, sightseeing and sipping vino under la luna then hold on to your capello because Barilla, Ruffino and Flight Centre have partnered up to give away a trip for two to Italy, redeemable until 2023.

Combining th e authentic Italian pasta roots of Barilla, the art of good living with wine producer Ruffino, and hand-picked holiday experiences from Flight Centre, this contest allows Canadians (excluding those in Quebec) to get excited about international adventures again.

Valid until 2023, the prize includes $4,000 in flight and hotel credit for two people provided by Flight Centre; a VIP tour of a Ruffino vineyard in Tuscany, including transportation, valued at $1,000; and $2,000 to spend on delicious food and beverages throughout the trip.

As long as you're the age of majority in your province or older, just head to the contest entry page and enter your name and email address to go in the draw to win. That's it!

And if you're willing to get creative in the kitchen, you can get a bonus entry by cooking one of these recipes and sharing it on Instagram; just tag and follow @barillacanada, @flightcentreca and @ruffinocanada and use the hashtag #BarillaPastaport. Delicious food and an extra chance to win a trip to Italy — who can say no to that?

With life for Canadians slowly but surely returning to normal (more or less), this contest couldn't have come at a better time.

Just imagine: once international travel is allowed again, you could be touring Tuscany's scenic vineyards, basking in the sun on the Amalfi Coast or marvelling at the history of the Roman Colosseum, gelato in hand.

Until then, you can travel with your palate to Tuscany, Liguria, Emilia-Romagna, Trentino, Lazio, Calabria and Sicily with these seven Italian recipes and wine pairings.

Try Penne With Shrimp & Cannellini Beans For A Taste Of Tuscany

Courtesy of Barilla

Nothing quite embodies the sophisticated simplicity of one of Italy's most famed destinations than penne with shrimp and cannellini beans. An ideal pairing with Ruffino Lumina Pinot Grigio, it's the extra virgin olive oil, which is a regional staple of Tuscany, that makes this dish soar. Serve with a generous grating of pecorino for a taste of Tuscany any day of the week.

Travel To Liguria With Basil Pesto Linguine

Situated along the Mediterranean coastline, Liguria is known for its fresh flavours that are the star of almost every dish, including linguine with basil pesto. Bright and herbaceous, it's the earthy pine nuts and zingy garlic that give fresh basil pesto its oomph. Don't forget to pair it with the smooth and clean-tasting Ruffino Orvieto Classico for an authentic Italian experience.

Take A Bite Of Emilia-Romagna With Rigatoni Bolognese 

Surprisingly understated and yet packed full of flavour, this dish is the embodiment of Emilia-Romagna itself: decadent, authentic and definitely worth experiencing.

Combining freshly grated parmesan cheese, ground beef and tomatoes, there's simply no going wrong, especially when coupled with Ruffino Modus 2017. Just one sip of this full-bodied wine is sure to transport your taste buds to Emilia-Romagna in an instant.

Take A Tour Of Trentino By Making Fettuccine With Wild Mushrooms

With a whole host of mushrooms to be found in the region of Trentino, this fettuccine dish is certain to deliver a little something of Italy no matter where in the world you are.

Though this recipe doesn't call for foraging the mushrooms themselves (a common pastime in Trentino throughout the fall), it's just as delicious as anything you'd find in the region itself, especially when paired with the medium-bodied Ruffino Chianti.

Relax In Lazio With Spaghetti Cacio E Pepe

Alexpro9500 | Dreamstime

Lazio is where you'll find the iconic Italian capital, Rome. Like the region by which it's inspired, this aromatic and appetizing spaghetti cacio e pepe recipe is a go-to classic. Pair it with the crisp and bubbly Ruffino Prosecco, and you have a match made in paradiso. It couldn't be easier either — all that's needed is a few minutes, a handful of ingredients and a fork to make this delicious dish yours.

Soak Up Calabria With 'Nduja & Octopus Ditali Pasta Salad

Courtesy of Barilla

Located at the very tip of Italy's "boot," Calabria is blessed on all sides by the bounty of the Ionian and Tyrrhenian Seas. This simple pasta salad brings together two iconic Calabrian ingredients — 'nduja and slow-cooked octopus. 'Nduja is a spread made from smoked pork and chillies and adds intense flavour to every dish it graces. A recipe like this needs a robust wine to stand up to its heat, which is why it pairs excellently with a Ruffino Chianti Classico Riserva Ducale.

Stop By Sicily With This Pasta Alla Norma 

Olena Danileiko | Dreamstime

Tender eggplant and tomato are at the heart of this iconic pasta dish from Sicily. Pairing this penne recipe with a nutty and fruity red wine, like the Ruffino Modus, will bring out the sweeter, caramelized flavour of the eggplant. After one bite of this simple, no-fuss recipe, you'll understand why it's such a classic dish.

With vibrant art, breathtaking landscapes, history and (of course) fabulous food, travelling through Italy is an experience well worth the effort. If you feel inspired, check out the sample packages put together by Flight Centre or reach out to one of their Travel Experts.

Whether you opt to tour some of the country's most iconic sites like the Trevi Fountain in Rome, Venice's Grand Canal, La Torre Pendente in Pisa, or settle in for some R&R along the Amalfi Coast, one thing's for sure — you're going to want a taste of Italy.

To learn more about how you can win a future trip to Italy, check out the official contest website.

Before you get going, check our Responsible Travel Guide so you can be informed, be safe, be smart, and most of all, be respectful on your adventure.

item.title: Voici toutes les régions qui passent en zone jaune dès la semaine prochaine au Québec
item.content:encoded:
Le plan de déconfinement bat son plein au Québec et le premier ministre a annoncé qu'à compter du 14 juin, neuf régions passeront en zone jaune.

En conférence de presse, François Legault a indiqué que « tout le Québec va être soit en jaune soit en vert ». Ainsi, dès lundi prochain, Montréal, la Capitale-Nationale, Laval, la Montérégie, les Laurentides, Lanaudière, l'Estrie, l'Outaouais et tout le Bas-Saint-Laurent vont passer du palier orange au jaune.

La situation de la pandémie continue de s’améliorer. Notre plan de déconfinement fonctionne et on peut même le deva… https://t.co/Qe36Gwmo9K
— François Legault (@François Legault) 1623171159.0

Avec ce changement de zone, les résident.es de ces régions pourront donc se rassembler dans une maison. Le nombre de personnes permis est limité aux occupants de deux adresses différentes seulement.

Pour ce qui est des rassemblements extérieurs privés, il faudra être huit personnes maximum ou bien deux bulles familiales seulement.

Au restaurant, les occupants de deux adresses pourront se réunir à une même table et « les bars, à partir de lundi, vont pouvoir rouvrir incluant à l'intérieur », a précisé François Legault.

La seule région qui inquiète le gouvernement est Chaudière-Appalaches; elle « devrait être en jaune lundi prochain mais si la situation s'empirait on va la laisser en orange ».

À noter que la Mauricie et Centre-du-Québec et le SaguenayLac-Saint-Jean vont également demeurer en zone jaune.

item.title: Les bals de finissants vont finalement être permis au Québec, mais pas à la fin de l'année
item.content:encoded:
Ce sont des milliers d'élèves du secondaire qui seront ravis que le gouvernement ait changé d'idée : les bals de finissant.es pourront avoir lieu au Québec. Toutefois, ils n'auront pas lieu au mois de juin, comme à l'habitude.

Après la création de plusieurs pétitions de la part de finissant.es du secondaire, le gouvernement du Québec et la santé publique ont changé leur fusil d'épaule et permettront la tenue de ces rites de passage vers le monde postsecondaire en juillet prochain.

La situation de la pandémie continue de s’améliorer. Notre plan de déconfinement fonctionne et on peut même le deva… https://t.co/Qe36Gwmo9K
— François Legault (@François Legault) 1623171159.0

« Je veux vous dire qu'on vous a bien entendu, tout le monde », affirme le premier ministre François Legault, en point de presse ce mardi 8 juin, ajoutant que l'on se rappelle tous de son bal. « Ç'a été mémorable et je voudrais que les jeunes aient ça dans leurs souvenirs. »

Pourquoi en juillet? « La majorité des jeunes devrait avoir reçu une dose d'ici le 24 juin », mentionne M. Legault, précisant qu'une dose de vaccin prend au moins deux semaines avant de faire effet. À partir du 8 juillet, il pourrait y avoir des bals à l'extérieur.

Pour un soir, les « rapprochements de toute sorte » seront permis, a affirmé François Legault. « Un vrai bal! »

En revanche, seules 250 personnes seront permises sous le même chapiteau extérieur.

En plus d'un bal des finissant.es, les élèves pourront avoir une remise des diplômes en présence des parents, en bonne et due forme. Il faudra toutefois respecter les règles sanitaires en place selon les régions.
